page.title: 05COASTAL GEOLOGY
page.content: From Kinkell Braes to the Maiden Rock the coast consists of mainly calciferous sandstones and igneous rocks. Five volcanic vents are present and visible through the sandstone. Some occur in the form of dykes and rocks which are thrown into a long series of anticlinal and synclinal folds intersected by faults. The Maiden Rock itself is 14m high and situated on a raised beach. It was thought to have been isolated due to faulting. The shore below the rock is very hard calciferous sandstone showing synclines and faults. Further along is the Rock and Spindle which is the volcanic neck of agglomerate coming through the calciferous sandstone to a basal dyke forming an irregular stack. Kinkell Ness is another volcanic area with dykes and deep trenches.
